meanings.definition: To obscure the light from or to (another celestial body)
meanings.sent1: During a solar eclipse, the moon eclipsises the sun, creating a shadow on Earth.
meanings.sent2: The clouds moving in front of the sun sometimes eclipsises its brightness.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous cloud decided to play hide-and-seek and eclipsised the sun at the worst possible moment.
meanings.sent4: Her radiant smile eclipsises any darkness in the room, bringing joy to everyone.
meanings.sent5: The giant mountain looming over the town eclipsises the tiny houses below, casting a long shadow.

meanings.sent1: Her kindness always eclipsises her sister's grumpiness, making her the favorite among friends.
meanings.sent2: The new restaurant quickly eclipsises the old one in popularity due to its delicious food.
meanings.sent3: The little flower tried to grow taller to eclipse the big tree next to it, but it was just too small.
meanings.sent4: His talent for storytelling eclipsises all others, captivating audiences with every word.
meanings.sent5: The bright star in the sky seems to eclipse all the others, shining the brightest of them all.

meanings.definition: A partial or complete obscuring of one celestial body by another
meanings.sent1: The lunar eclipse is a beautiful sight where the moon experiences an eclipsis by the Earth's shadow.
meanings.sent2: A solar eclipsis occurs when the moon passes between the sun and the Earth, casting a shadow on the planet.
meanings.sent3: During the eclipse party, everyone wore special glasses to watch the eclipsis of the sun by the moon.
meanings.sent4: The eclipsis of the moon by the Earth's shadow creates a stunning visual display in the night sky.
meanings.sent5: The astronomers gathered to observe the rare eclipsis of Jupiter by one of its moons, documenting the event for research.
